Expulsion from the city of Rome under the accusation of aggressive proselytizing among the Romans
Expulsion from the city of Rome by Emperor Tiberius together with practitioners of the Egyptian religion
King Philip IV expelled Jews from France largely to confiscate their property to fund wars
A final expulsion by Charles VI removed the Jewish population from France with most Jews fleeing to Eastern Europe and Poland
King Edward I issued the Edict of Expulsion removing all Jews from England
The Jewish community was formally readmitted to England ending the period of expulsion
A similar expulsion was issued from Portugal contributing to the spread of the Sephardic diaspora
Duke Albert V ordered the expulsion of Jews from Austria known as the Vienna Gesera
Pope Pius V expelled Jews from most of the Papal States allowing them to reside only in Rome and Ancona
Grand Duke Alexander expelled Jews from Lithuania; they were allowed to return in 1503
Following a blood libel accusation Jews were expelled from Brandenburg
Empress Maria Theresa ordered the expulsion of Jews from Prague; they were permitted to return in 1748
During the Black Death Jews were accused of poisoning wells and faced expulsions across German states
Jews were expelled from Warsaw Poland and not allowed to return until the late 18th century
Under Spanish rule Jews were expelled from the Kingdom of Naples
Duke Albrecht III expelled Jews from Upper Bavaria
Following the Black Death persecutions Jews were expelled from Strasbourg
Jews were expelled from Mainz a major center of Jewish learning
Jews were expelled from Cologne and not readmitted until 1798
Jews were expelled from Nuremberg by an order of the Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian I
After the death of Emperor Maximilian I Jews were expelled from Regensburg
Emperor Leopold I ordered the expulsion of Jews from Vienna
Empress Maria Theresa ordered the expulsion of Jews from Bohemia and Moravia; the order was rescinded in 1748
Jews were expelled from Hamburg but were later readmitted
Jews were expelled from Lübeck and not allowed to return until the mid-19th century
Vincent Fettmilch led a pogrom resulting in the expulsion of Jews from Frankfurt; they were readmitted two years later
Jews were expelled from the Netherlands but were later allowed to return
Jews were expelled from Breslau (now Wrocław Poland)
Jews were expelled from Erfurt Germany
Jews were expelled from Würzburg Germany
Jews were expelled from the Duchy of Pomerania
Jews were expelled from Mecklenburg Germany
Jews were expelled from Saxony Germany
Jews were expelled from Silesia (now part of Poland and the Czech Republic)
Jews were expelled from the Kingdom of Naples under Spanish rule
Jews were expelled from Genoa Italy
Jews were expelled from Milan Italy
Jews were expelled from the Duchy of Savoy
Pope Clement VIII expelled Jews from most of the Papal States allowing them to reside only in Rome and Ancona
King Louis I expelled Jews from Hungary; they were allowed to return in 1364
Jews were expelled from Hungary again under Emperor Rudolf II
King Ferdinand I ordered the expulsion of Jews from Bohemia; they were allowed to return in 1545
Jews were expelled from Bohemia again under Emperor Ferdinand I
Empress Maria Theresa ordered the expulsion of Jews from Bohemia; the order was rescinded in 1748
Empress Maria Theresa ordered the expulsion of Jews from Moravia; the order was rescinded in 1748
Jews were expelled from Galicia (now part of Poland and Ukraine)
During the Khmelnytsky Uprising Jews were massacred and expelled from parts of Galicia
Jews were expelled from parts of Poland following accusations of ritual murder
King John I Albert expelled Jews from Kraków; they were allowed to return in 1501
Jews were expelled from parts of Poland following accusations of desecrating the host
During the Swedish invasion of Poland Jews were expelled from various towns
Following the Bar Confederation Jews were expelled from parts of Poland
Following the Third Partition of Poland Jews were expelled from areas annexed by Prussia
Jews were expelled from villages and rural areas in Congress Poland
Following the Kraków Uprising Jews were expelled from Kraków
Following the assassination of Tsar Alexander II pogroms led to the expulsion of Jews from various towns
Following World War I Jews were expelled from parts of Poland during the Polish–Soviet War

titleEn: R. Moses of Lucca and son Kalonymus move to Mainz (920)
titleHe: ר' משה מלוקה ובנו קלונימוס עוברים למיינץ (920)
description: R. Moses of Lucca of N. Italy and son Kalonymus move to Mainz–becoming forefathers of German Jewish culture. Kalonymus' Responsa c. 940 are the oldest native products of Ashkenazi Jewry.
